Key Arguments: The bill advocates censorship and attacks free speech.
Misinformation and disinformation should be corrected in an open marketplace of ideas.
The bill unfairly targets digital platforms while ignoring mainstream media.
ACMA lacks the expertise to identify misinformation and disinformation accurately.
Government experts have previously been incorrect, as seen during COVID-19.
The bill could lead to politically biased enforcement.
The definitions of misinformation and disinformation are subjective and open to abuse.
The bill's provisions could lead to increased censorship and suppression of dissenting views.
Main Themes: Subjectivity and Bias in Defining Misinformation
Notable Quotes: I am totally opposed to this Bill as, contrary to assertions, it is advocating censorship and is an attack on Free Speech.
Misinformation or disinformation is best corrected in the open marketplace where contesting views can be analysed and adopted or debunked.

The definitions of misinformation and disinformation require ACMA to determine whether 'the content contains information that is false, misleading or deceptive'... Both parts of the definition are highly subjective.
